articles.headline: Shanahan Withdraws as Defense Secretary Nominee, and Mark Esper Is Named Acting Pentagon Chief
articles.snippet: As the F.B.I. investigated domestic violence, Patrick M. Shanahan said the confirmation process would “force my three children to relive a traumatic chapter in our family’s life.”
articles.abstract: As the F.B.I. investigated domestic violence, Patrick M. Shanahan said the confirmation process would “force my three children to relive a traumatic chapter in our family’s life.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday withdrew the nomination of Patrick M. Shanahan to be the permanent defense secretary, leaving the Pentagon in transition at a time of escalating tensions with Iran and questions about the role of the military on the border with Mexico.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Trump, at Rally in Florida, Kicks Off His 2020 Re-election Bid
articles.snippet: For a man who wants to be seen as an outsider despite occupying the Oval Office, the rally on Tuesday night presented an opportunity to, at least for one night, turn the clock back to 2015.
articles.abstract: For a man who wants to be seen as an outsider despite occupying the Oval Office, the rally on Tuesday night presented an opportunity to, at least for one night, turn the clock back to 2015.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — President Trump delivered a fierce denunciation of the news media, the political establishment and what he called his radical opponents on Tuesday as he opened his re-election campaign in front of a huge crowd of raucous supporters by evoking the dark messaging and personal grievances that animated his 2016 victory.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Annie Karni and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Google Pledges to Invest $1 Billion to Ease Bay Area Housing Crisis
articles.snippet: It’s the latest technology company to address a problem caused by the industry’s success.
articles.abstract: It’s the latest technology company to address a problem caused by the industry’s success.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 1998, Google paid $1,700 a month to rent its first office — half a home, including the garage, in Silicon Valley. What a deal.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: In Japan, It’s a Riveting TV Plot: Can a Worker Go Home on Time?
articles.snippet: On this show, a 30-something project manager in the famously overworked nation wants nothing more than to get out of the office and into her favorite bar for happy hour.
articles.abstract: On this show, a 30-something project manager in the famously overworked nation wants nothing more than to get out of the office and into her favorite bar for happy hour.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Last month, as Americans tuned in to the final episode of “Game of Thrones,” Japan was indulging in its own television fantasy world.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Eimi Yamamitsu

articles.headline: The Evangelical, the ‘Pool Boy,’ the Comedian and Michael Cohen
articles.snippet: Jerry Falwell Jr. defied expectations when he supported Donald J. Trump in 2016. Now details are emerging about behind-the-scenes maneuvering before the endorsement.
articles.abstract: Jerry Falwell Jr. defied expectations when he supported Donald J. Trump in 2016. Now details are emerging about behind-the-scenes maneuvering before the endorsement.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — Senator Ted Cruz was running neck and neck with Donald J. Trump in Iowa just before the caucuses in 2016, but his campaign was expecting a last-minute boost from a powerful endorser, Jerry Falwell Jr.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Black Superstars Pitch Adidas Shoes. Its Black Workers Say They’re Sidelined.
articles.snippet: Fewer than 4.5 percent of the workers at the company’s North American headquarters identify as black. Members of that small group say they feel ignored and sometimes discriminated against.
articles.abstract: Fewer than 4.5 percent of the workers at the company’s North American headquarters identify as black. Members of that small group say they feel ignored and sometimes discriminated against.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the United States, Adidas has built much of its name — and sales — through its association with black superstars. In the 1980s, the seminal hip-hop group Run-DMC gave the company’s sneakers and apparel cultural cachet through its song “My Adidas.” Popular black athletes and entertainers like James Harden, Candace Parker and Kanye West endorse its products.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: The Fed May Give Trump His Rate Cut. The Question Is When.
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged but opened the door to a future rate cut if risks to economic growth intensify.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged but opened the door to a future rate cut if risks to economic growth intensify.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump might get what he wants from the Federal Reserve, which kept interest rates steady on Wednesday but indicated that it could soon cut them as economic risks mounted and inflation remained stuck below target.

articles.headline: Saudis Called Khashoggi ‘Sacrificial Animal’ as They Waited to Kill Him
articles.snippet: A U.N. report reveals new details in the killing of the dissident journalist, and says that Crown Prince Mohammed must have been aware of the operation.
articles.abstract: A U.N. report reveals new details in the killing of the dissident journalist, and says that Crown Prince Mohammed must have been aware of the operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Key takeaways from the United Nations report on the killing of Jamal Khashoggi:
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Nick Cumming-Bruce
